subSubSection.paragraph: When alive, the delicate, semi-transparent expanded polyps are distinct and are up to 20 mm long, featuring eight pinnate tentacles (Figure 3A). The ROV photographs indicate that the colonies commonly grow on dead black corals; the latter may reach a large size (~45 cm in length) and can be predominantly fouled by A. delicata (Figure 3B). Interestingly, debris, such as PVC net found at a depth of 100 m, was found to be colonized by this octocoral (Figure 3C).

caption.paragraph: Figure 3. Altumia delicata gen. n. sp. n. live colonies. A, B colonies growing over branch of black coral with expanded polyps C colonies growing on PVC net (arrow heads).

subSubSection.paragraph: There are no differences between the holotype and the paratype except for the size of the colonies.
The species name is formed from the Latin ' delicata ', delicate, referring to the fine texture of the colonies and their polyps. Gender female.
